columns.text: This exercise requires us to explain the effect of the increase of dividend to the stock price.

Dividends can affect the stock price. Hence, the increase of stock prices is due to the increase of dividends not due to the effects of dividend policies of the company. Additionally, Dividend policies will always be irrelevant.
This exercise will determine the relationship of dividends and stock price.

### KEY TERMS

* **Dividends** - refers to the resources earned by the entity that is paid out to its shareholders. This may be in the form of cash, property, or stocks.

* **Dividend policy** - it serves as a guide for the board of directors in declaration of dividends. It contains all the provisions that are related to the schedule of distribution of dividends to the outstanding shareholders of the entity.

* **Stock price** - this is the amount that the buyers are willing to give to the issuing entity in exchange for the shares of stocks.

The dividends are **directly related** to the stock prices. The higher the dividends, the higher the stock price will be. The lower the dividends, the lower the stock price will be. This is because when the dividends declared increased, the potential investors who want to spend their money on such security will also increased making the price of stocks increased.

The increase on dividends and stock price are not influenced by the entityâ€™s dividend policy since it only guides the board of directors as to when the dividends will be declared, the date it will become ex-divided, the date of record, and the date of payment.

Entities pay dividends as a return on the investments of their shareholders. A persistent payment of dividends not only benefits the shareholders but also the entity since this shows how firm their earnings grow. This will eventually attract potential investors that will boost the stock price of the entity.
